texts.shortText: Fairly large species comprising multiple tall, erect fronds emerging from a well-developed holdfast. Colour deep-pink, often infused with an iridescent purplish-blue. Fronds flattened and give off alternating claw-like lateral branches, the margins of which are also serrated. Reproductive bodies form tiny clumps of leaf-like clusters in the axes of side branches.
Blades up to about 300 mm tall and about 7 mm wide.

Global: Mainly southern African, but also reported from Cape Verde Islands, Madagascar, Amsterdam and St Paul Islands.

Local/Regional: Yzerfontein on west coast to KwaZulu-Natal.
Distinctive and fairly common species on wave- exposed shores, occurring from low intertidal pools to a depth of about 5 m.

Has a complex life cycle consisting of three phases. The diploid sporophyte produces haploid spores which develop onto separate male and female gametophytes. These look similar to the sporophyte, except for details of the small fertile branches in the axils of the fronds. The female gametophyte retains her eggs while they are fertilised by the male gametes and develop into wart-like discs, and these are finally releases as asexual carpospores that develop back into the sporophyte generation!

There are several other much smaller regional species of Plocamium, all with curved branches, but this species is most likely to be confused with P. suhrii, which also has a blue hue, but is more delicate with frond only about 3 mm wide.
